answers.answer: I don't know anything about inductions, but I just wanted to tell you Good Luck!! You will have your little one soon! How exciting!
I was induced. After 26 hrs of not getting anywhere, i ended up having a c-section. Good luck
How far along in your pg were you when the dr induced?  Were you dialated at all?  What meds did they use?  jennimom

There are 2 main types of "pre-induction" meds they use...Cytotec and Cervidil.Cytotec is actually a pill that is used to treat ulcers, but somehow someone got the bright idea of putting it in a womans vagina to see what happened!  Hey!  Guess what???  It makes the cervix softer and more amenable to oxytocin.  It is usually inserted vaginally, but some places you take it by mouth.  There are usually multiple doses placed 2-4 hours apart.--the bad news is that occasionally it makes the uterus contract violently and continuosly.  The tablet is so small it usually cannot be retrieved from the vagina if this happens.  There are injectable medications that may stop the tetanic contractions, but this does not always work and if the baby cannot tolerate the contractions, an emergency C/S is done.  This does not happen often, but is not unheard of.The other med, Cervidil, looks a bit like a shoestring and is placed high up against the cervix.  The purpose is the same as Cytotec.  The main difference is that Cervidil CAN be removed (there is a string hanging out) in case of excessive contractions. The downside is that removing the Cervidil doesn't always stop the contractions and you end up with a C/S as described above.  Cervidil is placed once and left in place for 12 hours.Some people feel that Cervidil doesnt work quite as well as Cytotec, but I don't think there is a huge difference, myself.  Cervidil also costs upwards of $400 for one, and Cytotec costs about 25 cents.  So many docs are going with Cytotec.Occasionally, either med can put you right into labor without anything else having to be used.  Not common, but does happen.I know I probably made it all sound bad, but really both these meds are used frequently and there is a low incidence of adverse reactions.

My daughter was way overdue. They used Piticin or something like that. Labor started around 10am and she was born at 2:15pm. I begged for an epidural and dr didn't want to to do it. Said she would be here in an hour (Maybe around 1pm) but I couldn't deal w/ it anymore.It didn't help, I still felt the most painful pressure in the pelvic area. Then all of a sudden the nurse checked me and we had to get to the delivery room ASAP b/c she was on her way.

i was 37 weeks when i was induced. I went in at 6 pm and they placed a tiny little pill ( cant remember the name)on my cervix to make me thin. The next morning they started oxytocin through an iv to start my contractions. I only dilated 1 cm the whole time. Once my water broke, the contractions hit a lot harder.They couldnt believe i was only 1 because my contractions were so strong.i ended up having a c section 26 hrs later because i wasnt progressing. Good luck hope, i could help!!
Good luck to you! No matter how it happens, you'll have that baby in your arms on Sunday. That's exciting!

WHEN I HAD MY FIRST ONE I WAS ONLY 1 CM DIALATED, AND THEY PUT SOME KIND OF GEL ON MY CERVIX, CAN'T REMEMBER WHAT IT WAS CALLED BUT IT SOFTENED IT, AND THEN THEY PUT PITOCIN IN MY IV AND AT 3 CM THEY DID AN EPIDURAL, AND LIKE 14 HOURS LATER THERE WAS MY LITTLE BOY, SO DON'T WORRY, RELAX AND ENJOY THE WHOLE EXPERIENCEGOOD LUCK

Oh yeah.....the pill they used to soften my cervix was placed every 4 hrs during the night. They also have a 12 hr pill, but my dr said the 4 hr is more effective. Once they place the pill inside you, you have to lay straight back for 1 hour and after that you can sit up in bed but not get out...at least thats how it worked for me....

I was induced with my DS because the dr thought he was getting big and plus she was the one on call and OMG!!!!!!  Breaking my water was pure hell.  I had to have the epidural so they could do that.  It was a piece of cake afterwards so go with the epi.  I am not kidding.  I delivered in 7 hours because they were able to up the pitosin like every hour or so.  I felt nothing until push time.  Good luck to you.  Tomorrow you should be holding your baby.  How exciting.  Take Care

I was induced at 6pm on a Thursday with a prostaglandin gel placed in my cervix.  I was supposed to go back to the hospital at 6am the next day for a 2nd gel, but by 1am I was in labour, and went to the hospital where I was 6cm dilated (with the gel alone, although I was 11 days overdue!).  My labour stalled and I only went to 7 hours later, so I opted for an epidural so they could give me pitocin.  I didn't want pitocin without epidural!  My daughter was born at 2:45pm the next day.  It was a long time, but most of it was manageable.  Well, I say that now...I guess the further away you get from it, the easier it seemed - which is the only reason we have more than one child, right?!!  Anyway, good luck.  I was informed about the possibility of tetanic contractions as well, and the increased risk of C-section.  Likely everything will go smoothly!

I was induced for all 3 of my pregnancy.  They used potocin for all three and only the 2nd did they use something vaginally to soften the cervice.  1st I had toxcemia,  absolutley no meds, and the baby was sunny sid up.  Very, Very painful. Baby was deliever after 13 hours of intense pain. For my second my water broke at home around 11pm then by 11am contractions stopped.  I opted for an epidural as it was explained to me that the potocin will intensefy the contractions and there isn't as much of a rest between contractions.  Baby was deliver by 2:10 pm.  Then my last baby at my check-up when they did the ultrasound my fluid went from 12cc to 2cc they sent me to the hospital and induced baby was deliever 8 hours later.  Because of my high blood pressure my doctors starts at 34 weeks doing an ultrasound and non-stress test to keep close eye on baby and to make sure that I don't go into preeclampsia. Induction can cause the labor to be more painful, and that it doesn't always lead to c-section.  Also after the induction started I wasn't allowed out of the bed.  I had to use the bedpan when I had to go.  I would hold it as long as I could which is a bad thing to due because it causes unneccessary pain.   Good Luck and hoping that you have a wonderful(as it could possiblly be) delievery.

question: Just got back from the doctors' office. The baby looks good (about 7 lbs), but the amniotic fluid was lower than she'd like and the placenta is becoming a bit calcified.  So, as a precaution, she is going to induce on Sunday!  I am only 1 cm right now.  Anyone willing to share about the induction process?  They are having me come in Sunday morning early to start one mediation to further soften and open the cervix and then will move to labor inducing later in the day.  Dr said we should have our little boy by Sunday nite!!  Jennimom
title: Inducing on Sunday (38 weeks)
